div.p: Greetings. This excellent young man delivered your letters to me, which were welcome. I give thanks for them, which you conveyed, and I ask you, my dear Bullinger, to write when you have the truth of those matters I inquired about in my last letters. For this year, there will be serious dealings between the Emperor and the King; for the King does not want peace, nor will it happen, whatever the Emperor's men attempt, unless the German princes are involved, which I do not expect; for they cannot better bid farewell to their liberty. All is well with us. The whole of Corsica is French; if the Emperor's men, along with the Genoese, attack this winter, as they say, they will be met by brave men.

Otherwise, in France, it is quite peaceful except for the usual skirmishes, which occur on both sides at the borders. The Emperor's son is considering marrying the Queen of England; but now I hear that Milord Courtenay, whom the Queen has released from long imprisonment, will marry her. I am expecting the new secretary, who was with you, by the first post, and he will bring all the certain news from France, which I will immediately report. I greet the lords and you most affectionately. Farewell, excellent man. From Freiburg, November 3rd.
